Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Preoperative Exercise Training During Neoadjuvant Treatment for Gastro-Oesophageal Junction Cancer

Participants.evidence: Patients with resectable GOJ adenocarcinoma were allocated to either a standard-care control group or an exercise group

Intervention.evidence: allocated to either a standard-care control group or an exercise group, which included twice-weekly high-intensity aerobic and resistance training

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to assess the safety and feasibility of preoperative exercise training during neoadjuvant treatment.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) preventing surgery, measured from the start of neoadjuvant treatment to surgery.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty-two patients were enrolled between April 2016 and May 2017, with 21 in the exercise group and 29 in the control group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Sixty-two patients were enrolled between April 2016 and May 2017, with 21 in the exercise group and 29 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The risk of failure to reach surgery was 5% in the exercise group versus 21% in the control group (risk ratio 0.23, 95% CI 0.04 to 1.29).

Harms.evidence: No increase in SAEs was observed in the exercise group.
